skill.name: string-database
skill.description: Query STRING API for protein-protein interactions (59M proteins, 20B interactions). Network analysis, GO/KEGG enrichment, interaction discovery, 5000+ species, for systems biology.
skill.summary: Query STRING API for protein-protein interactions (59M proteins, 20B interactions). Network analysis...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: The string-database skill is a legitimate scientific tool for accessing protein-protein interaction data. All network requests are to the official STRING database API (string-db.org), and the code follows standard practices for scientific data access. The static analysis findings are false positives resulting from pattern-based detection of legitimate scientific operations.

content.user_title: Query protein interaction networks from STRING database
content.value_statement: Researchers need to understand protein-protein interactions to study biological systems and disease mechanisms. This skill provides direct access to STRING's comprehensive database of 59M proteins and 20B+ interactions across 5000+ species.
actual_capabilities: Query protein-protein interaction networks from STRING database
Map protein identifiers to STRING IDs
limitations: Requires internet connection to access STRING API
Limited to proteins available in STRING database
API rate limits apply (1 second between calls)
Large queries may timeout or require batching

use_cases.title: Analyze differentially expressed genes
use_cases.description: Upload a list of proteins from RNA-seq or proteomics experiments to identify enriched pathways and interaction networks.

use_cases.title: Study protein function and interactions
use_cases.description: Investigate specific proteins to discover interaction partners, visualize networks, and understand biological roles.

use_cases.title: Build and analyze biological networks
use_cases.description: Construct comprehensive interaction networks and test if proteins form significant functional modules.

prompt_templates.title: Basic protein network
prompt_templates.scenario: Find interactions for a single protein
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the protein interaction network for TP53 in humans with medium confidence (400), including 5 additional nodes, and save as PNG image.

prompt_templates.title: Functional enrichment
prompt_templates.scenario: Analyze a gene list from experiment
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform functional enrichment analysis on these proteins: TP53, BRCA1, ATM, CHEK2, MDM2. Show GO biological processes with FDR < 0.05.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-species comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Get interaction networks for p53 protein in human (9606) and mouse (10090) with high confidence (700), then compare the top 10 interactors.

prompt_templates.title: Pathway analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this DNA repair protein list: map IDs, get interaction network with 700 confidence, test PPI enrichment, perform GO/KEGG enrichment, and generate evidence-colored network image.

output_examples.input: Get interaction partners for BRCA1 with high confidence
output: â€¢ BRCA2 - DNA repair protein, 990 confidence
â€¢ PALB2 - BRCA2 binding protein, 980 confidence
Network contains 5 high-confidence interactions supporting BRCA1's role in homologous recombination repair.

best_practices: Always map protein identifiers first using string_map_ids for faster queries
Use appropriate confidence thresholds: 400 for standard, 700 for high-confidence analyses
Include species parameter for networks with more than 10 proteins
Wait 1 second between API calls to respect rate limits
anti_patterns: Don't query with more than 100 proteins in a single call - split large lists
Avoid using very low confidence thresholds (< 150) without biological justification
Don't ignore species specification for multi-protein networks
Never hardcode protein identifiers without validating them first

faq.question: What is the STRING database?
faq.answer: STRING is a comprehensive database of protein-protein interactions covering 59M proteins and 20B+ interactions across 5000+ organisms, integrating data from experiments, databases, and text-mining.

faq.question: Which species are supported?
faq.answer: STRING supports 5000+ species. Common ones include human (9606), mouse (10090), rat (10116), fly (7227), yeast (4932), and zebrafish (7955).

faq.question: What confidence threshold should I use?
faq.answer: Use 400 for standard analysis, 700 for high-confidence interactions, and 150 for exploratory analysis. Higher thresholds give fewer but more reliable interactions.

faq.question: How do I cite STRING?
faq.answer: Cite the latest STRING publication from https://string-db.org/cgi/about. The data is freely available under Creative Commons BY 4.0 license.

faq.question: Can I analyze more than 100 proteins?
faq.answer: Yes, but split large lists into batches of 100 or fewer proteins to avoid timeouts and ensure optimal performance.

faq.question: What's the difference between functional and physical networks?
faq.answer: Functional networks include all evidence types (recommended for most analyses). Physical networks only show direct binding evidence (for structural studies).
